entry.title: Olympiad Solutions are Up!
entry.summary:
Math Updates

New Content

After some months of working on new problems and doing write-ups (both on paper and digitally), I present you the Olympiad corner!

Before you dive in, be sure to read through this section on my math page.

The initial batch of problems range across the four areas (A, C, N, G) pretty evenly, with some problems coming from multiple areas. There are twenty-five problems in total, and the difficulty is on the easier side compared to harder Olympiads. The selection consists of problems I've solved which I found interesting, cute, instructional, prototypical, and/or anything in between.

Hopefully, the number of problems on this list will grow over time, and as I gain more experience, the difficulty and diversity will also broaden.

Unfortunately, I do not have geometry diagrams yet, so you'll have to make do without them for now... sorry :(

Math Tech... more like Math TeX!

I decided to go with KaTeX for math rendering. The syntax is pretty much the same as LaTeX and it just works. The nice thing about KaTeX is that it adheres to the single responsibility principle: it only renders math. The mess of formatting then becomes the responsibility of the client. Although this sounds like a nuisance, on the flip side, it means that the client gets full control over the page layout. You may miss theorem numbering and proof environments, but that comes with it the hidden assumption that the document is static. The dynamic web, however, has a whole host of tools that allows you to present math in unconventional ways. KaTeX simply gets out of the way and allows you to do just that.

For Olympiad solutions, my write-ups are stored and organized using a tool called VON. It maintains modular chunks of math that I can freely cut and paste wherever I want. This gives me a single source of truth for any math I write digitally. Want to add a problem to an article or book? Go to the source and add \voninclude{PROBLEM_SOURCE}. Want to retrieve a problem statement for an app or site? Run a subprocess with

von show "PROBLEM_SOURCE" -b 0

Then, all I need to do is update VON, and the changes become reflected everywhere!

For my build process, I have a simple shell script that pulls Olympiad data from VON, converts LaTeX to KaTeX readableThe syntax that KaTeX expects is a bit different from traditional TeX/LaTeX (no dollar signs, environments wrapped in display mode), but good ol' PCRE's got my back. form, and writes the output to temporary files. This is then read by my static site generator to be integrated with anything added through markdown (including custom extensions).

Nice-To-Haves and Things-To-Fix

Aside from the major update, before I forget, I'll mention a few minor things I want add or fix for the site. This may or may not happen any time soon...

  1. Add a custom 404 page
  2. Fix the URL slugs for the generated Atom feeds
  3. Make the ID/URL generation for image galleries consistent across builds
  4. Add syntax highlighting for code blocks?

Nano Life Updates/Plans

A few months ago, I decided to order a programmable mechanical keyboard, and now that I have it, I feel a lot faster compared to when I was only using my laptop keyboard. This is especially true after having done twenty-five write-ups. Although this may just be placebo...

Besides that, for the next few months, I'll probably get back into software. I have things I want to hack for Zedigo(æ”¹). If things go well, maybe an MVP will be on the horizon?

entry.title: Folklore Combinatorics/4
entry.summary:
Maximally Parasocial

At a social gathering of introverts, it was found that for each pair of people, exactly one of them knew the other. Prove that there was someone in the gathering that each person either knew or knew someone else who did.

Solution

Call the person that was known to the most number of people \(A\). We claim that person \(A\) is the one with the desired properties.

Suppose the number of people who knew \(A\) was \(k\). If \(A\) did not know anyone in the gathering, then everyone must have known \(A\) so our work is done. Otherwise, \(A\) must have known someone else, say person \(B\). It then suffices to show that \(B\) knew someone that knew \(A\).

If \(B\) did not know anyone else who knew \(A\), then clearly, \(B\) must not have known the \(k\) people who knew \(A\). Thus, \(B\) must have been known to the \(k\) people who knew \(A\). And since \(A\) knew \(B\), in total, \(B\) must have been known by \(k+1\) people. This contradicts the maximality of the number of people who knew \(A\), so our assumption that \(B\) did not know anyone who knew \(A\) is false. \(B\) must have known someone who knew \(A\).

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

This is a prototypical example of an existence problem where we discover the construction through the extremal principle. We hypothesize that the desired object maximizes some function, and if said hypothesis is in fact true, the solution should come out via assuming falsity and arriving at some contradiction.

entry.title: USAMO 1995/3
entry.summary:
Perpendicular Bisectors and the Lemoine Point

Given a nonisosceles, nonright triangle \(ABC\), let \(O\) denote the center of its circumscribed circle, and let \(A_1\), \(B_1\), and \(C_1\) be the midpoints of sides \(BC\), \(CA\), and \(AB\), respectively. Point \(A_2\) is located on the ray \(OA_1\) so that \(OAA_1\) is similar to \(OA_2A\). Points \(B_2\) and \(C_2\) on rays \(OB_1\) and \(OC_1\), respectively, are defined similarly. Prove that lines \(AA_2\), \(BB_2\), and \(CC_2\) are concurrent, i.e. these three lines intersect at a point.

Solution

The main claim is that \(AA_2\), \(BB_2\), and \(CC_2\) are the symmedians of \(\triangle{ABC}\).

WLOG, we show that \(AA_2\) is the \(A\)-symmedian of \(\triangle{ABC}\). By the symmedian construction, it suffices to prove that \(\angle OBA_2 = 90^\circ = \angle OCA_2\). The given similar triangles yield \[ OA_1 \cdot OA_2 = OA^2 = OB^2.\] Then, we have \(OB^2 = OA_1 \cdot OA_2 \iff \frac{OB}{OA_1} = \frac{OA_2} {OB}\) and \(\angle BOA_1 = \angle BOA_2\). Hence, triangles \(BOA_1\) and \(A_2OB\) are similar. Since \(OA_1\) is the perpendicular bisector of side \(\overline{BC}\), \(\angle OBA_2 = 90^\circ\). These arguments can be repeated for \(\angle OCA_2\), so we get \(\angle OBA_2 = 90^\circ = \angle OCA_2\) as desired.

\(BB_2\) and \(CC_2\) are then also symmedians of \(\triangle{ABC}\) and it is well known that the symmedians of a triangle concur at the Lemoine point.

\(\blacksquare\)

entry.title: USAMO 1995/2
entry.summary:
Broken Calculator with Trig

A calculator is broken so that the only keys that still work are the \( \sin\), \( \cos\), and \( \tan\) buttons, and their inverses (the \( \arcsin\), \( \arccos\), and \( \arctan\) buttons). The display initially shows \( 0\). Given any positive rational number \( q\), show that pressing some finite sequence of buttons will yield the number \( q\) on the display. Assume that the calculator does real number calculations with infinite precision. All functions are in terms of radians.

Solution

Define the set \(\sqrt\mathbb{Q} \coloneqq \{\,q > 0 \mid q^2 \in \mathbb{Q}\, \} \supset \mathbb{Q}\). Let us then define the functions \(f,g: \sqrt\mathbb{Q} \to\sqrt\mathbb{Q}\) from the calculator buttons. We have \[f(r) \coloneqq \tan\left(\arcsin\left(\cos\left(\arctan r\right)\right)\right) = \tan\left(\frac{\pi}{2} - \arctan r\right) = \frac{1} {r},\] and \[g(r) \coloneqq \cos\left(\arctan r\right) = \frac{1} {\sqrt{1 + r^2}}.\] Obviously \(f\) is bijective because its inverse is defined as itself. On the other hand, \(g\) is also bijective as its inverse is defined as \(g^{-1}(r) = \tan\left(\arccos r\right) = \frac{\sqrt{1-r^2}}{r}\) where \(r\) is in the range of \(g\).

Suppose we are given some number \(q\in\sqrt\mathbb{Q}\) to compute. Starting at \(0\), we can first apply \(\cos\) to get \(1\). We then show that it is possible to iteratively apply \(f\) and \(g\) a finite number of times to achieve \(q\). Since \(f\) and \(g\) are bijective, this is equivalent to showing that we can iteratively apply inverses \(f^{-1}\) and \(g^{-1}\) a finite number of times to get from \(q\) to \(1\).

Define a function \(c: \sqrt \mathbb{Q} \to \sqrt \mathbb{Q}\) as \[ c(q) \coloneqq \begin{cases} f^{-1}(q) = \frac{1}{q} & \text{if } q > 1 \\ 1 & \text{if } q = 1 \\ g^{-1}(q) = \frac{\sqrt{1-r^2}}{r} & \text{if } 1 > q > 0 \end{cases}. \] We prove that \[ \underbrace{c(c(c(... c}_n(q) ...))) = 1,\] for some positive integer \(n\).

Letting \(q = \sqrt\frac{a}{b} = \frac{\sqrt a}{\sqrt b}\), for relatively prime \(a, b \in \mathbb{Z}^{+}\), we get the following cases: If \(a > b\), then \(c(q) = c\left(\frac{\sqrt a}{\sqrt b}\right) = \frac{\sqrt b} {\sqrt a}\). If \(a=b\), then \(c(q) = 1\). If \(b > a\), then \[ c(q) = c\left(\frac{\sqrt a}{\sqrt b} \right) = \frac{\sqrt{1 - \frac{a}{b}}}{\sqrt\frac{a}{b}} = \frac{\sqrt {b - a}}{\sqrt a} .\]

We don't need to consider when \(a = b\), since it clearly satisfies our claim. Now consider the sum of the squares of the numerator and the denominator when \(q\) maps to \(c(q)\). For \(q,\) this sum is initially \(a+b\). For \(c(q)\), we either get \(b+a\) or \(b - a + a = b\). Since \(b + a\), \(b \leq a + b\), notice that every application of \(c\) monotonically decreases this sum by a positive integer. It is also impossible to have infinite applications of the first case where this sum doesn't decrease, so enough applications of \(c\) must bring the sum down until \(a = b = 1\), at which point we are done.

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

We want nestings of functions to yield rational values, so there are certain cases that scream \(\textit{don't go there!}\) Expressions like \(\sin \sqrt k\), \(\cos \sqrt k\), \(\arcsin \frac{m\pi}{n}\), \(\arccos \frac{m\pi} {n}\), etc. are such examples. In particular, we don't want ratios of the sides of a traingle holding factors of \(\pi\). The angle conditions can be a little more relaxed because we can define the angle whose slope is some rational \(q\).

So it's rather clear that there will be two kinds of numbers that appear on the calculator. Those that represent angles and those that represent side ratios. To get all the rational numbers, we will most likely focus on extracting it from side ratios. There is also alternation between angle values and ratio values. Therefore, it's practically impossible to have a repeat of the same kind of trig function; it must alternate between \(\sin\), \(\cos\), and \(\tan\) to one of their inverses.

We can try listing all possible ways of mapping these functions to see what happens. Begin with some triangle side ratio \(t\) (not necessarily rational). \(t\) can map to the following: \[\begin{align*} f_1(t) &= \cos\left(\arctan t\right) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + t^2}} \\ f_2(t) &= \sin\left(\arctan t\right) = \frac{t}{\sqrt{1 + t^2}} \\ f_3(t) &= \tan\left(\arcsin t\right) = \frac{t}{\sqrt{1 - t^2}} \\ f_4(t) &= \tan\left(\arccos t\right) = \frac{\sqrt{1 - t^2}}{t} \end{align*}\]

We will now try to get all the rationals. Consider what it means for some rational number \(m\) to be \(\textit{computable}.\) If it were computable, then persumably, from the above logic, it will come out of one of \(f_1(t)\), \(f_2(t)\), \(f_3(t)\), or \(f_4(t)\). So let's just see what happens when we let \[ m = f_1(t) . \]

For the relation to hold, we must have \[\begin{align*} &\quad m = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 + t^2}} \\ \iff&\quad m^2\left(1 + t^2\right) = 1 \\ \iff&\quad m^2t^2 = 1 - m^2 \\ \iff&\quad t^2 = \frac{1 - m^2}{m^2} \\ \iff&\quad t = \frac{\sqrt{1 - m^2}}{m}, \end{align*}\] where each equation above is bidirectional since \(m\), \(t > 0\).

So if \(m\) is computable, then \(t\) must again be computable from one of \(f_1\), \(f_2\), \(f_3\), or \(f_4\). We can then try the above method again, reach another value \(t_1\), and send that back into, say \(f_1\), and so on. Once we hit a value we know for certain is computable, then we know that unwinding all the operations should give us a valid way to compute \(m\). This can be seen for the value \(q = \frac{4}{5}\) below:

\[q = \frac{4}{5} \ {\color{blue} \to} \ \frac{3}{4} \ {\color{blue} \to} \ \frac{\sqrt 7}{3} \ {\color{blue} \to} \ \frac{\sqrt 2}{\sqrt 7} \ {\color{blue} \to} \ \frac{\sqrt 5}{\sqrt 2} \ {\color{red} \to} \ \frac{\sqrt 2}{\sqrt 5} \ {\color{blue} \to} \ \frac{\sqrt 3}{\sqrt 2} \ {\color{red} \to} \ \frac{\sqrt 2}{\sqrt 3} \ {\color{blue} \to} \ \frac{1}{\sqrt 2} \ {\color{blue} \to} \ 1 \ {\to} \ 0\]

The blue arrows indicate computing \(t\) from \(m\) as above. The red arrows indicate computing the reciprocal.

entry.title: Folklore Combinatorics/3
entry.summary:
Graph Connectedness Guaranteed

If a graph has \(n\) vertices, what is the minimum number of edges it must have to guarantee that it is connected?

Solution

The answer is \(\tbinom{n-1}{2} + 1 = \frac{(n-1)(n-2)}{2} + 1\) edges. We first show that our answer indeed connects any given graph.

Consider a graph \(G\) that has at least \(\frac{(n-1)(n-2)}{2} + 1\) edges and assume FTSOC that there exists some \(k\)-vertex subgraph of \(G\) (\(k < n\)), say \(G_k\), that is disconnected. The degree of each vertex in \(G_k\) must be at most \(k-1\). Similarly, among the remaining \(n-k\) vertices, since none of them connect to vertices in \(G_k\), each vertex will have a degree at most \(n-k-1\). Now if the number of edges in \(G\) is maximized, by the handshake lemma, the total number of edges in \(G\) must be at most \[ \frac{k(k-1)}{2} + \frac{(n-k) (n-k-1)} {2}.\]

Hence, if \(E\) is the total number of edges in \(G\), we must have \[\begin{align*} &\quad \frac{k(k-1)}{2} + \frac{(n-k)(n-k-1)}{2} \geq E \geq \frac{(n-1)(n-2)}{2} + 1 \\ \implies&\quad\frac{k(k-1)}{2} + \frac{(n-k)(n-k-1)}{2} \geq \frac{(n-1)(n-2)}{2} + 1 \\ \iff&\quad\frac{n^2-(2k+1)n+2k^2}{2} \geq \frac{n^2-3n+4}{2} \\ \iff&\quad k^2 - (k-1)n - 2 \geq 0 \\ \iff&\quad k - 2 \geq (k-1)(n-k), \end{align*}\] which is a contradiction.

It now suffices to show that \(\frac{(n-1)(n-2)}{2} + 1\) is the minimum possible bound. If the bound is \(\frac{(n-1)(n-2)}{2} = \tbinom{n-1}{2}\), then there is a counterexample of \(G\) as the union of a \(K_{n-1}\) complete graph and one disconnected vertex. On the other hand, there does exist a graph with \(\tbinom{n-1}{2} + 1\) edges; \(G\) can be a \(K_{n-1}\) complete graph connected to a distinct vertex by one edge.

\(\blacksquare\)

entry.title: Canada 1991/3
entry.summary:
Midpoints Lie on a Circle

Let \(C\) be a circle and \(P\) a given point in the plane. Each line through \(P\) which intersects \(C\) determines a chord of \(C\). Show that the midpoints of these chords lie on a circle.

Solution

Let \(O\) be the center of circle \(C\). The diameter of \(C\) passing through \(P\) passes through the midpoint \(O\), so the locus contains \(O\). Now consider the midpoint \(Q\) (\(\neq O, P\)) of some chord \(q\) passing through \(P\). Since \(Q\) bisects chord \(q\), note that \(OQ\) is perpendicular to \(q\). In other words, \(\angle OQP = 90^\circ\). As such, \(Q\) lies on the circle whose diameter is \(OP\). This is true regardless of the choice of \(q,\) so any midpoint \(Q\) will lie on the circle with diameter \(OP\).

\(\blacksquare\)

entry.title: Monge's Theorem
entry.summary:
Fun with Menelaus' Thoerem

Suppose we are given three non-congreuent circles in the plane. It is possible to draw the external tangents for each pair of circles so that they intersect at a point. Prove that these points are collinear.

Solution

Let the three circles be \(\omega_1\), \(\omega_2\), and \(\omega_3\), and their centers be \(O_1\), \(O_2\), and \(O_3\) respectively. Furthermore, let \(X\) be the intersection of the tangents between \(\omega_1\), \(\omega_2\), and define \(Y\) and \(Z\) similarly.

WLOG, consider a single external tangent between, say, \(\omega_1\) and \(\omega_2\). If we let the point of tangency on \(\omega_1\) be \(M\) and the point of tangency on \(\omega_2\) be \(N\), then clearly, \(M\), \(N\), \(X\) are collinear. Moreover, \(\measuredangle O_1MX = 90^\circ = \measuredangle O_2NX\), and \(O_1\), \(O_2\), \(X\) are collinear. Thus, \(\triangle{O_1MX}\) is similar to \(\triangle{O_2NX}\) with \[ \left|\frac{O_1X}{O_2X}\right| = \left|\frac{O_1M} {O_2N}\right| = \frac{r_1}{r_2},\] where \(r_1\) and \(r_2\) are the radii of \(\omega_1\) and \(\omega_2\) respectively. Thus, it also follows that \(\left|\frac{O_2Y}{O_3Y}\right| = \frac{r_2}{r_3} \), and \(\left|\frac{O_3Z} {O_1Z}\right| = \frac{r_3}{r_1}\).

Finally, consider the points \(O_1\), \(O_2\), and \(O_3\). If the points are collinear, the theorem is obviously true; all the intersections lie on a line. On the other hand, if the points form a triangle \(\triangle{O_1O_2O_3}\), then we get a case of Menelaus' Theorem. \[\frac{O_1X}{XO_2}\cdot\frac{O_2Y}{YO_3} \cdot\frac{O_3Z}{ZO_1} = \left(-\frac{r_1}{r_2}\right)\left(-\frac{r_2} {r_3}\right)\left(-\frac{r_3}{r_1}\right) = -1,\] where the length ratios are directed.

\(\blacksquare\)

entry.title: Japan 2009/4
entry.summary:
Shooting Lemma on an Angle Equality

Let \(\Gamma\) be the circumcircle of triangle \(ABC\). A circle with center \(O\) is tangent to side \(BC\) at point \(P\) and tangent to the arc \(BC\) of \(\Gamma\) not containing \(A\) at point \(Q\). Prove that if \(\angle{BAO} = \angle{CAO}\), then \(\angle{PAO} = \angle{QAO}\).

Solution

Let \(M\) be the midpoint of arc \(BC\) containing \(A\), \(N \neq A\) be the intersection of line \(AO\) with \(\Gamma\), \(O_{\Gamma}\) be the center of \(\Gamma\), and \(\omega\) be the circle with center \(O\) described in the problem statement.

\(M\), \(P\), and \(Q\) are then collinear by the so called \(\textit{shooting lemma}\), which we prove as follows. It is clear that there exists a homothety mapping \(\omega\) to \(\Gamma\), since \(O_\Gamma\), \(O\), and \(Q\) are collinear, \(MO_{\Gamma} \) is parallel to \(PO\) (both perpendicular to \(\overline{BC})\), and both \(\triangle{MO_{\Gamma}Q}\) and \(\triangle{POQ}\) are isosceles. Consequently, \(M\), \(P\), and \(Q\) are collinear.

We now claim that \(M\), \(O_{\Gamma}\), \(N\) are also collinear. We have \[ \measuredangle CBN = \measuredangle CAN = \measuredangle CAO = \measuredangle OAB = \measuredangle NAB = \measuredangle NCB, \] so \(N\) must be the midpoint of arc \(\widehat{BC}\) not containing \(A\). Thus, \(MN\) is simply the diameter of \(\Gamma\).

We now use the above to show that \(A\), \(P\), \(O\), \(Q\) are concyclic. Using the homothety defined above, we see that \[ \measuredangle OPQ = \measuredangle O_{\Gamma}MQ = \measuredangle NMQ = \measuredangle NAQ = \measuredangle OAQ, \] so \(A\), \(P\), \(O\), \(Q\) are concyclic.

Lastly, since \(\triangle{OPQ}\) is isosceles, \[ \measuredangle QAO = \measuredangle QPO = \measuredangle OQP = \measuredangle OAP. \]

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

Once the configuration for the shooting lemma is found, the key observation is that \(A\), \(P\), \(O\), and \(Q\) are concyclic. This requires discovering point \(N\) along the way, which is both the antipode of \(M\) and the intersection of \(AO\) with \(\Gamma\).

entry.title: Folklore Number Theory/2
entry.summary:
Relatively-Prime Reciprocals Sum to 1/2

For some positive integer \(n \geq 2\), suppose \(p\) and \(q\) are relatively prime positive integers such that \(p < q \leq n\) and \(p + q > n\). If \(\mathcal{R} _n\) is the set of all ordered pairs \((p, q)\), prove that \[\sum_{(p,q) \in \mathcal{R}_n} \frac{1}{pq} = \frac{1}{2}.\]

Solution

Given a set of positive integer pairs \(X = \{\left(a_1, b_1\right), \left(a_2, b_2\right), \dots, \left(a_n, b_n\right)\}\), define the function \(\sigma:X\to \mathbb{Q}\) as \[ \sigma(X) \coloneqq \sum_{(a,b) \in X}\frac{1}{ab}.\] Moreover, define the sets \(A_n \coloneqq \{(p,q)\in \mathcal{R}_n \mid p+q>n+1\} \), \(B_n \coloneqq \{(p,q) \in \mathcal{R}_n \mid p+q=n+1\}\), and \(N_n \coloneqq \{(p, n) \in \mathcal{R}_n\} \). We derive a few properties of these sets.

By construction, \(A_n\) and \(B_n\) are disjoint sets such that \(A_n \cup B_n = \mathcal{R}_n\) (ie. \(A_n = \mathcal{R}_n \setminus B_n\)). Furthermore, since the sum of each pair in \(A_n\) is greater than \(n+1\) and follow the conditions satisfied by \(\mathcal{R}_n\), the pairs appear in the set \(\mathcal{R}_{n+1}\). In other words, \(A_n \subset \mathcal{R}_{n+1}\).

\(N_n\) is also the complement of \(A_{n-1}\) with respect to \(\mathcal{R}_{n}\). \(A_{n-1} \subset \mathcal{R}_n\) from before, and each element of \(A_{n-1}\) is a pair whose greatest element is at most \(n-1\). Likewise, \(N_n \subset \mathcal{R} _n\), but each element of \(N_n\) is a pair whose greatest element is exectly \(n\). These sets therefore disjointly make up \(\mathcal{R}_n\).

We have shown that \(A_n \sqcup B_n = \mathcal{R}_n = A_{n-1} \sqcup N_n\), so it is clear that \[\sigma(A_n) + \sigma(B_n) = \sigma(\mathcal{R}_n) = \sigma(A_{n-1}) + \sigma(N_n)\] for each \(n > 2\).

We then proceed to prove by induction that \(\sigma(\mathcal{R}_n) = \frac{1} {2} \) for each \(n > 2\) (\(n=2\) is trivially true). The base case is \(n=3\), for which \(\mathcal{R}_3 = \{(1,3), (2,3)\}\), and \(\sigma(\mathcal{R} _3) = \frac{1} {3} + \frac{1}{6} = \frac{1}{2}\). Now suppose that for some integer \(k > 2\), \(\sigma(\mathcal{R}_k)=\frac{1}{2}\). By the equalities derived above, we have \[\begin{align*} \sigma(\mathcal{R}_{k+1}) &= \sigma(A_k) + \sigma(N_{k+1}) \\ &= \sigma(\mathcal{R}_k) - \sigma(B_k) + \sigma(N_{k+1}) \\ &= \frac{1}{2} + \sigma(N_{k+1}) - \sigma(B_k). \end{align*}\] Thus, it suffices to show that \(\sigma(N_{k+1}) = \sigma(B_k)\) for each \(k>2\).

We now prove a short lemma. For positive integers \(a\), \(b\), and \(m\) such that \(a+b=m\), \(a\perp m \iff a\perp b \iff b\perp m\). By symmetry, it suffices to prove that \(a\perp m\) if and only if \(a\perp b\). The Euclidean algorithm yields \(\gcd(m, a) = \gcd(a, m - a = b)\), so if one of them is \(1\) then so is the other.

Let us now compute \(\sigma(N_{k+1})\). We have \[\begin{align*} \sigma(N_{k+1}) &= \sum_{\substack{0<p<k+1\\ p\perp k+1}} \frac{1}{p(k+1)} \\ &= \frac{1}{2}\cdot\sum_{\substack{0<p<k+1\\ p\perp k+1}}\left(\frac{1}{p(k+1)}+\frac{1}{(k+1-p)(k+1)}\right) \\ &= \frac{1}{2}\cdot\sum_{\substack{0<p<k+1\\ p\perp k+1}}\frac{1}{p(k+1-p)} \\ &= \sum_{\substack{0<p<q\leq k\\ p+q=k+1\\ p\perp q}}\frac{1}{pq} \\ &= \sum_{\substack{(p,q)\in \mathcal{R}_k\\ p+q=k+1}}\frac{1}{pq} = \sigma(B_k), \end{align*}\] where our lemma is used on the second and the fourth equalities.

We have shown that \(\sigma(N_{k+1})=\sigma(B_k)\) for each \(k>2\), completing the proof.

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

The main difficulty of this problem is to get the whole induction to go through. We want to somehow link the \(n=k\) case to the \(n=k+1\) case, but simple computations of the sum do not yield anything fruitful. This motivates us to analyze the actual pairs instead. We see that some of the pairs appear multiple times across \(n\), so we question whether we have anything useful to say about them. One of the key realizations is to notice that if pair \((p, q) \in \mathcal{R}_k\) has the property \(p+q>k+1\), then that pair carries over to the next sum for \(n=k+1\). It is then easy to realize that the rest of the pairs that make up \(\mathcal{R}_{k+1}\) have largest element \(k+1\). This motivates the three sets we defined in the solution.

Beyond this, the rest of the problem simplifies to showing that the sums from these sets are equal. The insight here is that numbers relatively prime to some integer \(k\) come in pairs that sum to \(k\). This is the lemma we proved in the solution.

entry.title: BAMO 1999/3
entry.summary:
Color Switcher

A lock has \(16\) keys arranged in a \(4 \times 4\) array, each key oriented either horizontally or vertically. In order to open it, all the keys must be vertically oriented. When a key is switched to another position, all the other keys in the same row and column automatically switch their positions too. Show that no matter what the starting positions are, it is always possible to open this lock. (Only one key can be switched at a time.)

Solution

It suffices to show that there exists a sequence of moves such that any of the keys can be switched individually without altering the rest of the configuration.

Select any key to individually switch and call this the \(\textit{main}\) key. Now consider all the keys that occupy the same row or the same column as this key. Together, there are \(7\) such keys including the main key. We claim that our sequence of moves consists of switching each of these keys once regardless of order.

To prove that this works, we count the number of times each key gets switched. There are three cases to consider: the main key, the \(6\) other keys to switch, and the rest of the keys left untouched.

For the main key, the position changes each time we switch one of the \(7\) keys. Since \(7\) is odd, by the end of the operation, it will switch to a different position.

Meanwhile, for the other \(6\) keys, a key either shares the same row or the same column as the main key. WLOG, if the key shares the same row with the main key, then when the \(7\) keys get switched, only the keys in the same row affect our key. Hence, any such key gets switched \(4\) times, returning them to their original positions.

Lastly, for the untouched keys, a key will share the same row with one of the \(6\) keys, and share the same column with another of the \(6\) keys. This means that untouched keys are switched a total of \(2\) times, so they too will switch back to their original positions.

We have shown that only the main key gets switched to a different position after the sequence of moves, so we are done.

\(\blacksquare\)

Commentary

The solution can easily be generalized for any even by even array. On the other hand, when the array has odd dimensions, there seem to be certain invariants preventing potential solutions. I haven't investigated the problem enough, so I can't say for sure.

entry.title: Folklore Combinatorics/2
entry.summary:
Number of Non-Adjacent Subsets

How many subsets of \(\{1, 2, \dots, 100\}\) are there that do not contain adjacent numbers?

Solution

Let \(a_n\) be the number of subsets of \(\{1, 2, \dots, n\}\) that do not contain adjacent numbers. We claim that \(a_n = F_{n+2}\), where \(F_n\) denotes the \(n\)-th Fibonacci number.

First, let us compute the first two values of \((a_n)\). When \(n=1\), we have the subsets \(\{\emptyset, \{1\}\}\), so \(a_1=2\) and when \(n=2\), we have the subsets \(\{\emptyset, \{1\}, \{2\}\}\), so \(a_2=3\). It now suffices to prove that \(a_n = a_{n-1} + a_{n-2}\).

Consider the numbers \(1\), \(2\), \(\dots\), \(n\). We do casework on whether to include or exclude \(n\) in our subset.

Suppose we include \(n\). This means that we cannot include \(n - 1\). The exclusion of \(n-1\) does not affect the inclusion of the rest of the numbers between \(1\) and \(n-2\), so there will be \(a_{n-2}\) subsets that can be formed with these numbers.

On the other hand, if we exclude \(n\), then this does not affect the inclusion of the rest of the numbers from \(1\) to \(n-1\). Therefore, there will be \(a_{n-1}\) subsets that can be formed.

We have therefore shown that \(a_n = a_{n-1} + a_{n-2}\), so \(a_{n} = F_{n+2}\). Our particular problem asks for the case when \(n = 100\), so \[a_{100} = F_{102} = \boxed{927,372,692,193,078,999,176}.\]

\(\blacksquare\)

entry.title: Folklore Combinatorics/1
entry.summary:
Counter on the Edges of a Cube

On a cube, seven verticies are labeled with \(0\)s and the remaining vertex is labeled with a \(1\). An operation consists of choosing an edge of the cube and incrementing the numbers at the endpoints by \(1\). Can all the numbers be (i) equal, or (ii) divisible by 3 after a finite number of these operations?

Solution

(i) is impossible for parity reasons. Updating an edge increases the total sum of the vertices by \(2\), the initial configuration starts with an odd sum, and the the sum of the vertices in the desired configuration is even (\(8k\) where \(k\) is the quantity on each vertex).

(ii) is more interesting. Suppose we two-color the vertices of the cube, that is, color the vertices with two colors, say black and white, in such a way that adjacent vertices have different colors. Let \(B\) be the sum of the black vertices and \(W\) be the sum of the white vertices.

WLOG, assume that the \(1\) in the initial configuration is on a black vertex. We start with \(B=1\) and \(W=0\). An update to an edge increases each of \(B\) and \(W\) by \(1,\) so their difference is invariant (ie. \(B - W = 1\)). The desired end state where each of the \(8\) numbers is divisible by \(3\) requires \(B - W\) to be divisible by \(3\) so the desired goal is impossible.

\(\blacksquare\)

entry.title: Folklore Number Theory/1
entry.summary:
Divisibility of 2n Numbers

Among \(n + 1\) positive integers \(\leq 2n\), prove that there are two which are relatively prime and two where one divides the other.

Solution

We first show that there exist two relatively prime numbers.

For each positive integer \(k \leq 2n\), \(\gcd(k, k+1) = 1\). Pairing each odd \(k\) with \(k+1\), we get \(n\) pairs among which \(n + 1\) numbers are chosen. By the pigeonhole principle, there must exist a pair where both numbers are chosen.

Next, we show that there exist two numbers where one divides the other.

Define an \(\textit{odd root}\) of a positive integer \(k\) as the odd positive integer \(r\) such that \(k = 2^t\cdot r\) for some non-negative integer \(t\). We partition the positive integers from \(1\) to \(2n\) based on their odd root. Since there are \(n\) odd positive integers, clearly there will be \(n\) partitions.

We now claim that any two numbers in the same partition have the property that one divides the other. Suppose WLOG that positive integers \(a\) and \(b\) have the same odd root \(r_0\) and \(a > b\). We can write \(a\) as \(2^{a_0}\cdot r_0\) and \(b\) as \(2^{b_0} \cdot r_0\) for some non-negative integers \(a_0\) and \(b_0\). Since \(a > b\), clearly, \(a_0 > b_0\), so \[a = 2^{a_0}\cdot r_0 = 2^{a_0 - b_0} \cdot 2^{b_0} \cdot r_0 = 2^{a_0 - b_0}\cdot b.\]

Among the \(n\) partitions, \(n+1\) numbers are chosen, so by the pigeonhole principle, there must exist a partition in which two numbers are chosen.

\(\blacksquare\)

entry.title: Folklore Algebra/1
entry.summary:
The Mean-Map of a Sequence

Let the \(\textit{mean-map}\) of a finite sequence of real numbers be a new sequence where each term in the original sequence is replaced by the arithmetic mean of the term and the next term after it (where the last term is paired with the first term). If we start with a sequence of integers where no two terms are equal, then prove that iteratively taking the mean-map of the seqeunce will eventually produce non-integral terms.

Solution

We will first prove the following assertion.

If \(q_1\), \(q_2\), \(\dots\), \(q_n\) \((n > 2)\) is a seqeunce of pairwise distinct integers, then no matter how many times the mean-map is taken, a seqeuence will never have all equal terms.

Assume FTSOC that at some point all the terms become equal. Suppose the sequence \(r_1\), \(r_2\), \(\dots\), \(r_n\) of integers are not all equal and the map \[ \left(r_1, r_2, \dots, r_n\right) \mapsto \left(\frac{r_1+r_2} {2}, \frac{r_2+r_3} {2}, \dots, \frac{r_n+r_1} {2}\right) \] yields \[\frac{r_1+r_2}{2} = \frac{r_2+r_3}{2} = \dots = \frac{r_n+r_1}{2} \iff r_1+r_2 = r_2+r_3 = \dots = r_n+r_1.\]

If \(n\) is odd, then we derive that \(r_1 = r_2 = \dots = r_n\), contradicting the fact that they are not all equal. It suffices to then consider the case when \(n\) is even.

If \(n\) is even, the above equality yields \(r_1 = r_3 = \dots = r_{n-1}\) and \(r_2 = r_4 = \dots = r_n\). Suppose that \(x = r_1\) and \(y = r_2\). If \(x=y\), then we get a contradiction as in the odd case, so consider \(x\neq y\). It suffices to show that there cannot exist a sequence of integers \(s_1\), \(s_2\), \(\dots\), \(s_n\) such that \[ \left(s_1, s_2, \dots, s_n\right) \mapsto \left(x, y, \dots, x, y\right).\] If such a sequence exists, then \(s_1 + s_2 = s_3 + s_4 = \dots = s_{n-1} + s_n = 2x\) and \(s_2 + s_3 = s_4 + s_5 = \dots = s_n + s_1 = 2y\). From which it follows that \(\sum_{i=1}^n s_i = nx\) and \(\sum_{i=1}^n s_i = ny\) respectively. However, since \(x \neq y\), this is clearly a contradiction.

Lastly, we show that the sum of the pairwise distances between terms always decreases. Let \(D_k\) be the sum after taking \(k\) mean-maps, we have \[\begin{align*} D_k &= \sum_{1\leq i\leq j\leq n} \left| q_i - q_j \right|\\ &= 2\sum_{1\leq i\leq j\leq n} \frac{\left| q_i - q_j \right|}{2} \\ &= \sum_{1\leq i\leq j\leq n} \frac{\left| q_i - q_j \right| + \left| q_{i+1} - q_{j+1} \right|}{2} \\ &> \sum_{1\leq i\leq j\leq n} \left|\frac{q_i + q_{i+1}}{2} - \frac{q_j + q_{j+1}}{2}\right| \\ &= D_{k+1}, \end{align*}\] where indicies are taken cyclically modulo \(n\).

Since \(D_k \geq 0\) always decreases after taking a mean-map and the terms never equate to one another (\(D_k \neq 0\) for each \(k\)), eventually \(D_k\) will stop decreasing by integers, at which point it will decrease by a non-integer. The distance between terms will then be non-integral, so some term must become non-integral.

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

There are two key insights to the solution. The first insight is to come up with the monovariant \(D_k\): the sum of the pairwise distances between terms. Enough experimentation should reveal that the terms seem to "converge" together after enough mean-maps. This then motivates the next key insight which is to question whether all the terms become equal. This is important because the equality case is a fixed point under a mean-map. To guarantee that we always get non-integral terms, we must eliminate the potentially unwieldly cases where the configurations somehow jumps to this fixed point. Once these two insights are found however, the rest are minor details.

entry.title: Canada 2015/2
entry.summary:
An Inequality on the Product of Altitude Components

Let \(ABC\) be an acute-angled triangle with altitudes \(AD\), \(BE\), and \(CF\). Let \(H\) be the orthocentre, that is the point where the altitudes meet. Prove that \[\frac{AB\cdot AC + BC\cdot BA + CA\cdot CB}{AH\cdot AD + BH\cdot BE + CH\cdot CF} \leq 2.\]

Solution

I should come back to clean up this solution because it's embarrassingly long... But nonetheless, here is a solution:

Let \(a\), \(b\), \(c\) denote the lengths of the sides \(BC\), \(AC\), and \(AB\) respectively. We begin with an obvious statement of AM-GM: \[ab + bc + ca \leq a^2 + b^2 + c^2\] is equivalent to \[\begin{align*} \frac{1}{a} + \frac{1}{b} + \frac{1}{c} &\leq \frac{a^2 + b^2 + c^2}{abc} \\ &= \frac{\left(c^2 + b^2 - a^2\right) + \left(a^2 + c^2 - b^2\right) + \left(a^2 + b^2 - c^2\right)}{abc} \\ &= 2\left(\frac{\cos A}{a} + \frac{\cos B}{b} + \frac{\cos C}{c}\right). \end{align*}\]

Now suppose \(x = c\cdot AF\), \(y = a\cdot BD\), and \(z = b\cdot CE\). We claim that \[\begin{align*} x\cos B\cos C &= \frac{xyz}{a^2bc},\\ y\cos C\cos A &= \frac{xyz}{ab^2c}, \\ z\cos A\cos B &= \frac{xyz}{abc^2}. \end{align*}\]

By the symmetry of the configuration, WLOG it suffices to show that \(x\cos B\cos C = \frac{xyz}{a^2bc}\). We have \[\begin{align*} x\cos B\cos C &= c\cdot AF\cdot\cos B\cos C \\ &= (c\cos B)\cdot AF\cdot\cos C \\ &= BD\cdot AF\cdot \frac{CE}{a} \\ &= \frac{xyz}{a^2bc}. \end{align*}\]

Multiplying both sides of our derived inequality by \(\frac{xyz}{abc}\), we get \[\begin{align*} &\quad \sum_{cyc}\frac{xyz}{a^2bc} \leq 2\sum_{cyc}\left(\frac{xyz}{a^2bc}\cos A\right)\\ \iff&\quad \sum_{cyc}x\cos B\cos C \leq 2(x+y+z)\cos A\cos B\cos C\\ \iff&\quad \frac{x}{\cos A} + \frac{y}{\cos B} + \frac{z}{\cos C} \leq 2(x+y+z), \end{align*}\]

where the cyclic sum is taken across the triplet \((a\), \(b\), \(c)\), the triplet \((x\), \(y\), \(z)\), and the triplet \((A\), \(B\), \(C)\). Also note that \(0 < \cos A\), \(\cos B\), \(\cos C < 1\) since \(ABC\) is acute. Now observe that \[ \frac{x} {\cos A} = \frac{c\cdot AF}{\cos A} = \frac{c\cdot AF\cdot b}{AF} = bc,\] as well as \(\frac{y}{\cos B}=ab\) and \(\frac{z}{\cos C} = ca\). Furthermore, it is well known that the points \(F\), \(B\), \(D\), \(H\), the points \(H\), \(D\), \(C\), \(E\), and the points \(E\), \(A\), \(F\), \(H\) are respectively concyclic, so by the power of a point,

\[\begin{align*} x &= c\cdot AF = AH\cdot AD, \\ y &= a\cdot BD = BH\cdot BE, \\ z &= b\cdot CE = CH\cdot CF. \end{align*}\]

Substituting for the inequality above gives us \[ \frac{AB\cdot AC + BC\cdot BA + CA\cdot CB}{AH\cdot AD + BH\cdot BE + CH\cdot CF} \leq 2.\]

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

The motivation for the solution is to think about how to interpret each product that appears in the expression on the left-hand side. Initially, the products \(AB\cdot AC\), \(BC\cdot BA\), and \(CA\cdot CB\) motivate us to think about area, but this line of thought is shot down by the fact that \(\sin\) doesn't give us the lengths we care about. The lengths we care about are the ones that appear in the problem statement as well as the ones that can be derived from power of a point.

With this train of thought however, one might reach the critical insight, which is that \[AB\cdot AC\cdot\cos A = AB\cdot AC\cdot \frac{AE}{AB} = AE\cdot AC = AH\cdot AD,\] where the same relation holds for the other angles. A natural train of thought is: if \(\sin\) didn't work, why not \(\cos\)? Or one can realize that \(AE\) is the projection of \(AB\) onto side \(AC\). Or instead of thinking about areas, think about dot products. Any one of these should lead to this key insight.

From here, the problem becomes substantially easier, so the rest is mostly algebraic and geometric grunt work.

entry.title: Canada 2011/2
entry.summary:
Parallelogram in Cyclic Quadrilateral

Let \(ABCD\) be a cyclic quadrlateral whose opposite sides are not parallel, \(X\) the intersection of \(AB\) and \(CD\), and \(Y\) the intersection of \(AD\) and \(BC\). Let the angle bisector of \(\angle AXD\) intersect \(AD\), \(BC\), at \(E\), \(F\) respectively and let the angle bisector of \(\angle AYB\) intersect \(AB\), \(CD\) at \(G\), \(H\) respectively. Prove that \(EFGH\) is a parallelogram.

Solution

We show that \(EF\) bisects \(HG\) and vice versa. To begin, let \(Z = XF\cap YH\). We then compute the value of \(\angle XZY\): \[\begin{align*} \angle XZY &= \angle EZY \\ &= 180^\circ - (\angle EYZ + \angle ZEY) \\ &= 180^\circ - (\angle EYZ + \angle EXA + \angle XAE) \\ &= 180^\circ - (\angle DYH + \angle FXB + \angle DCB) \\ &= 180^\circ - \left[\frac{1}{2}\left(\widehat{CD} - \widehat{AB}\right) + \left(\widehat{BC} - \widehat{DA}\right) + \angle DCB\right] \\ &= 180^\circ - \left(\frac{1}{2}\widehat{BCD} - \frac{1}{2}\widehat{DAB} + \angle DCB \right) \\ &= 180^\circ - \left(\frac{1}{2}\angle BAD - \frac{1}{2}\angle DCB + \angle DCB \right) \\ &= 180^\circ - \frac{1}{2}\left(\angle BAD + \angle DCB \right) \\ &= 180^\circ - 90^\circ = 90^\circ. \end{align*}\]

Thus we deduce that \(XZ\) is perpendicular to \(YZ\). Now consider \(\triangle{HXG}\) and \(\triangle{EYF}\). Segments \(\overline{XZ}\) and \(\overline{YZ}\) are each both an angle bisector and an altitude of \(\triangle{HXG}\) and \(\triangle{EYF}\) respectively. It follows that the triangles are both isosceles, and in particular, \(XZ\) bisects \(\overline{HG}\) and \(YZ\) bisects \(\overline{EF}\). \(E\) and \(F\) are on \(XZ\), and \(G\) and \(H\) are on \(YZ\) respectively, so the result has been proven.

\(\blacksquare\)

entry.title: Canada 2015/1
entry.summary:
Functional Inequality in N

Let \(\mathbb{N} = \{1, 2, 3, \dots\}\) be the set of positive integers. Find all functions \(f\), defined on \(\mathbb{N}\) and taking values in \(\mathbb{N} \), such that \((n-1)^2 < f(n)f(f(n)) < n^2 + n\) for every positive integer \(n\).

Solution

We claim that the only solution to \(f\) is \(f(n)=n\). Clearly, the inequality \[\ (n-1)^2 < f(n)f(f(n)) = nf(n) = n^2 < n^2 + n \] holds. We then show that \(f(n) = n\) for each \(n \in \mathbb{N}\).

To begin, we prove by induction that \(f(n)\geq n\) for each \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). The base case is \(n = 1\), where in which \(0 < f(1)f(f(1)) < 2\). This implies that \(f(1) = 1\). Now suppose that \(f(k)\geq k\) for each \(1 \leq k \leq n - 1\), and assume FTSOC that \(f(n) < n\). Since \(f(n)\) is in \(\mathbb{N}\), we know that \[\begin{align*} &\quad f(n) < n \\ \iff&\quad f(n) \leq n - 1 \\ \implies&\quad f(n)^2 \leq (n-1)^2 < f(n)f(f(n)) \\ \implies&\quad f(n) < f(f(n)). \end{align*}\]

However note that because \(1 \leq f(n) \leq n-1\), by the hypothesis, \(f(f(n)) \geq f(n)\). This is a contradiction, so \(f(n) \geq n\) completes the induction.

We then show that \(f(n) \not> n\) for each \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). Suppose that \(f(n) > n\). We then have \[\begin{align*} &\quad f(n) > n \\ \iff&\quad f(n) \geq n + 1 \\ \implies&\quad f(n)^2 \geq (n+1)^2 > n^2+n > f(n)f(f(n)) \\ \implies&\quad f(n) > f(f(n)). \end{align*}\]

But clearly, by the fact that \(f(n) \geq n\) for each \(n\), it must be that \(f(f(n)) \geq f(n)\). This is a contradiction, so \(f(n) \not> n\).

In conclusion, we have shown that \(f(n) = n\) for each \(n\), so the only function \(f:\mathbb{N} \rightarrow \mathbb{N}\) must be \(f(n)=n\).

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

This is a typical garden-variety functional \(\sout{\text{equation}}\) inequality.

Observing that \(f\) is defined in \(\mathbb{N}\), we are motivated to test small values of \(n\). At first, the experimentation will make the problem smell like number theory, but after a while, we observe a recursive structure in the bounds. From here, we guess that the answer is just \(n\), and the usage of strong induction is highly motivated.

The only point of caution is to not get \(\textit{for each}\) mixed up with \(\textit{for some}\). This is the infamous point-wise trap. When we say that \(f(n) \geq n\), we must specify whether this is true for some particular value of \(n\), or for each \(n \in \mathbb{N}\). The distinction seems subtle, but the consequences are dire. For example, if \(f(n) \geq n\) is for true for each \(n\), then we can safely conclude that \(f(f(n)) \geq f(n)\), whereas if the argument is only true for some \(n\), we cannot make such conclusions.

In fact, there are lines of logic that are even more seemingly subtle than what is described above. The famous one is the distinction between \(\textit{for each} \) and \(\textit{for all}\). Intuitively, they seem interchangeable (\(\forall\)), but they can mean completely different things depending on the context. In these cases, leaning towards for each is a good bet.

entry.title: Canada 2014/1
entry.summary:
Lower Bound on a Finite Fractional Sum

Let \(a_1, a_2, \dots, a_n\) be positive real numbers whose product is \(1\). Show that the sum \[\sum_{i=1}^n \frac{a_i}{\prod_{j=1}^i (1+a_j)}\] is greater than or equal to \(\frac{2^n - 1}{2^n}\).

Solution

Define \[P_n \coloneqq \prod_{i=1} ^n(1+a_i) \quad\mathrm{and}\quad S_n \coloneqq \sum_{i=1}^n \left[a_i\prod_{j=i+1}^n(a_j + 1)\right].\]

We first show that \(S_n = P_n - 1\) by induction. The base case is \[\begin{align*} S_2 &= a_1(1 + a_2) + a_2 \\ &= a_1 + a_1a_2 + a_2 \\ &= (1 + a_1)(1 + a_2) - 1 \\ &= P_2 - 1. \end{align*}\] Now suppose that the claim is true for \(n=k\). \[\begin{align*} S_{k+1} &= (1 + a_{k+1})(P_k - 1) + a_{k+1} \\ &= (1 + a_{k+1})P_k - 1 - a_{k+1} + a_{k+1} \\ &= P_{k+1} - 1, \end{align*}\] completes the induction.

The expression in the problem statement can be rewritten as \(\frac{S_n}{P_n}\). Since \(a_1a_2\dots a_n = 1\), by the AM-GM inequality, \[ P_n = \prod_{i=1} ^n(1+a_i) \geq 2^n\sqrt{a_1a_2\dots a_n} = 2^n.\] Therefore, \[\begin{align*} &\quad\frac{1}{2^n} \geq \frac{1}{P_n} \\ \iff&\quad 1 - \frac{1}{P_n} \geq 1 - \frac{1}{2^n} \\ \iff&\quad \frac{P_n - 1}{P_n} \geq \frac{2^n - 1}{2^n} \\ \iff&\quad \frac{S_n}{P_n} \geq \frac{2^n - 1}{2^n}. \end{align*}\]

\(\blacksquare\)

entry.title: USAJMO 2010/2
entry.summary:
Mysterious Sequence in N

Let \(n > 1\) be an integer. Find, with proof, all sequences \(x_1, x_2, \dots, x_{n-1}\) of positive integers with the following three properties: (a) \(x_1 < x_2 < \dots < x_{n-1}\); (b) \(x_i + x_{n-i} = 2n\) for all \(i = 1, 2, \dots, n-1\); (c) given any two indices \(i\) and \(j\) (not necessarily distinct) for which \(x_i + x_j < 2n\), there is an index \(k\) such that \(x_i + x_j = x_k\).

Solution

We claim that the answer is only the sequence \(2, 4, 6, \dots, 2n - 2\). It is easy to verify that all of the conditions are met. (a) and (b) are trivial. To verify (c), note that if we divide each of the terms by \(2\), the resulting sequence is simply the sequence of integers from \(1\) to \(n-1\). Since \(x_i + x_j < 2n\) is equivalent to \(\frac{x_i}{2} + \frac{x_j}{2} < n\), we know that there exists some index \(k\) for which \(\frac{x_i}{2} + \frac{x_j}{2} = \frac{x_k}{2}\), where \(\frac{x_k}{2}\) is one of the integers between \(1\) and \(n-1\).

We then show that this is the only sequence that works. We claim that \[\begin{align*} x_1 + x_{n-2} &= x_{n-1} \\ x_1 + x_{n-3} &= x_{n-2} \\ &\vdots \\ x_1 + x_2 &= x_3. \end{align*}\]

To begin, note that \[x_1 < x_2 \iff x_1 + 2n - x_2 < 2n \iff x_1 + x_{n-2} < 2n. \] By condition (c), there exists some term whose sum is \(x_1 + x_{n-2}\). Since \(x_1 + x_{n-2} > x_{n-2},\) the only possibility is \(x_{n-1}\).

Next, observe that \(x_{n-3} < x_1 + x_{n-3} < x_1 + x_{n-2} = x_{n-1} < 2n\) so it follows that \(x_1 + x_{n-3} = x_{n-2}\). Repeating the logic \(n-3\) more times, we discover that the system of equations in the claim holds.

We now show that \(x_2 = 2x_1\). We have \[\begin{align*} &\quad x_1 + x_{n-2} = x_{n-1} \\ \iff&\quad x_1 + 2n - x_2 = 2n - x_1 \\ \iff&\quad x_2 = 2x_1. \end{align*}\]

Substituting the above into our equations and iteratively substituting thereafter, we find that \(x_2 = 2x_1\), \(x_3 = 3x_1\), \(\dots\), \(x_{n-2} = (n-2)x_1\), and \(x_{n-1} = (n-1)x_1\). Since \(2n - x_1 = x_{n-1} = (n-1)x_1\), we derive that \(x_1 = 2\). Therefore the only sequence is \(2, 4, 6, \dots, 2n-2\).

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

Once we derive the main claim that \(x_1 + x_{n-i} = x_{n-i+1}\) for each \(1 < i < n - 1\), the rest of the solution becomes details. The motivation for the key claim is to realize that the sum with the maximal gap between terms is extremely (no pun intended) well-defined. Then, it's easy to \(\textit{tip}\) the dominoe to get all the other equalities. This is a nice problem where analyzing extremities does wonders.

entry.title: Canada 2012/2
entry.summary:
LCM of Common Numbers

For any positive integers \(n\) and \(k\), let \(L(n,k)\) be the least common multiple of the \(k\) consecutive integers \(n\), \(n+1\), \(\dots\), \(n+k-1\). Show that for any integer \(b\), there exist integers \(n\) and \(k\) such that \(L(n, k) > bL(n + 1,k)\).

Solution

\(\gdef\lcm{\operatorname{lcm}}\)

Given any positive integer \(b\), let \(p>b\) be an odd prime number. We claim that \(n=p^2\), \(k=2p\) satisfies the condition.

Let \(C\) be the least common multiple of all the integers \(p^2+t\) where \(t\) ranges from 1 and \(2p-1\) inclusive. Since \(p^2\nmid p^2+t\) for each \(t\), we have \[L(n,k) = L(p^2, 2p) = \lcm(p^2, C) = pC.\] Furthermore, \[L(n+1, k) = L(p^2+1, 2p) = \lcm(p^2+2p, C) = C.\] The last line follows from the fact that \(p^2+2p=p(p+2)\), where both \(p\) and \(p+2\) are within the range of \(t\). In other words, there must exist multiples of \(p\) and \(p+2\) among the \(2p-1\) consecutive integers that produce \(C\).

As such, we conclude that \[L(n,k) = pC = pL(n+1,k) > bL(n+1, k).\]

\(\blacksquare\)

Motivation

The motivation for the solution is to notice that \(L(n,k)\) and \(L(n + 1, k)\) doesn't change "by much". This is in the sense that the least common multiples that these expressions are evaluating basically the same thing except the first or last term in a sequence of consecutive integers. This motivates us to invent \(C\), the least common multiple of the "common" numbers between each sequence.

The rest of the solution stems from trying to control the behavior of \(C\) to not take too many or too few factors given arbitrary \(n\) and \(k\). This is a construction problem, so once an example is found, we're done.
